That water in the furnace was boiling, no question about it. Just because only one side of the bowl had enough heat flux to vigorously boil the water doesn't mean the rest of the water in the bowl wasn't at boiling temperature. The water would have been circulating quite a bit because of natural circulation so the water on one side of the bowl would be replaced by the water on the other side within seconds, and thus the whole bowl would be at boiling temperature.

Think about it, you wouldn't say that the water you're using to boil your pasta isn't boiling just because it is only vigorously boiling at the bottom, and not on the sides or top. The water at the sides and top are at boiling temperature, there's just not enough heat flux to make nucleate boiling in those particular areas.

I have not done it in a long time... but you can in fact boil water inside of a paper cup. This is not practical but is a great physics experiment to show how the water and the cup create a system and that the cup will not burn until it reaches it's burning point, 451, while the water boils at 212... Of course the edges of the cup do in fact burn off, but you are able to boil water in a paper cup.

3:30 Since it is thermally less conductive, it apparently cannot conduct the heat to the water fast enough. The temp of the bowl rises. I know book paper burns at 451F, so for everyday purposes, I use that figure for anything wood-based. Once the bowl reached about that temp, it ignited. Very interesting to observe.
The hot plate test is even more interesting, considering the element would be hot enough to ignite the bowl, but maybe it wasn't able to conduct the heat from the plate. I now wonder how a thermal exchange between wood/metal versus wood/air differs. Is there a table somewhere with coefficients?
